Psychophysiological Changes: Geranium oil inhalation—both state and trait scores were significantly lowered.

Odorant Materials: Ylang-ylang, orange, geranium, cypress, bergamot, spearmint, and juniper
Psychophysiological Changes: Cypress produced favorable impression after physical work and juniper produced favorable impression after mental work.
Relaxant effect—lower level of state anxiety, a more positive mood, and a higher level of calmness.
Inhalation of favorite odors suppresses the muscle sympathetic vasoconstrictor activity and attenuates the blood pressure increase by affecting the central nervous system higher than the midbrain.
Carvone—subjective restlessness. Prolonged inhalation of fragrances influences autonomic nervous system parameters as well as mental and emotional conditions.
Essentials oils or their components on basic forms of attention behavior are mainly psychological.
Lavender odorants were associated with reduced mental stress and increased arousal rate.
Enhanced physical performance and generating more push-ups and running faster.

Odorant Materials: Isovaleric acid, thiophenol, pyridine, l-menthol, isoamyl acetate, and 1,8-cineole
Psychophysiological Changes: Autonomic variations in response to olfactory stimuli—along two main dimensions of pleasantness and arousal.

Odorant Materials: Pepper oil, estragon oil, fennel oil or grapefruit oil, rose oil or patchouli oil
Psychophysiological Changes: Fragrance inhalation of rose oil or patchouli oil caused a 40% decrease in relative sympathetic activity.
Treatment of agitated behavior in patients with severe dementia.

Odorant Materials: Peppermint oil, jasmine oil and dimethyl sulfide
Psychophysiological Changes: Peppermint odor reduced received work load and effort and increased self-evaluated physical performance and energy.
Lavender produced a significant decrease in performance of working memory. Rosemary produced a significant enhancement of performance for overall quality of memory.
Both rosemary and lavender scents were associated with lower mean ratings on the fatigue-inertia subscale, relative to the control group.
Relaxing odors decreased heart rate and skin conductance, with stimulating odors producing reverse effects under equivalent conditions.
Alter affective appraisal of the experience and consequent retrospective evaluation of treatment-related pain.
Increased the percentage of deep or slow-wave sleep in men and women and decreased rapid-eye movement sleep.
Reduced fatigue and improved mood and was rated as more pleasant, intense, stimulating, and elating than water.
Performance improvement in the presence of peppermint odor when the response mapping was incompatible but not in the compatible condition.
Jasmine tea, lavender and (R)-(−)-linalool increased positive mood state.
Reduced anxiety and improved mood in patients waiting for dental treatment.
Daytime sleepiness, peppermint oil can indeed reduce sleepiness.
During recesses—higher concentration levels for lavender group
More calm and more relaxed.
Caffeine led to improved speed and accuracy on cognitive tasks and increased alertness when compared with chewing.
Sedative effect
Aromatherapy massage exerts positive effects on anxiety and self-esteem.

Odorant Materials: With or without lavender-scented bath oil
Psychophysiological Changes: Mothers—more relaxed, and smiled. Infants—cried less and spent more time in deep sleep.
Increased relaxation.
Ortho- and retronasal odor presentation—route of odor presentation has direct implications for the enjoyment of foods and drinks.
Peppermint enhanced memory whereas ylang-ylang impaired it, peppermint increased alertness and ylang-ylang decreased it.
Reduced sleepiness and improved refreshment at awakening for participants who suffered from insomniac symptoms.
Reduced the stress levels and the pain intensity of needle insertion.
Cognitive tasksare significantly related to concentration of absorbed 1,8-cineole following exposure to rosemary aroma.
Pain and inflammatory responses after total knee replacement.

Odorant Materials: Bergamot essential oil and synthetic oil
Psychophysiological Changes: Relieved work-related stress of teachers with various workloads and had a weak effect on young teachers who had a heavy workload.
Relaxation of bronchial smooth muscles, increased ventilation and brain oxygen concentration, and decreased blood lactate level.

Odorant Materials: Basil, bergamot, cardamom, cinnamon, juniper, lemon, orange, plamarosa, peppermint, sandalwood, spearmint and ylang-ylang
Psychophysiological Changes: Essential oils may have versatile psychophysiological potencies.
